verses.text: Many have undertaken to arrange an account of the things that have been fulfilled among us,
verses.comment: Luke begins with the acknowledgment that others have compiled accounts, referring to the widespread knowledge of Jesus' life and works. Shows the early community's interest in preserving the tradition.

verses.text: Just as those who were eyewitnesses from the beginning and servants of the word handed them down to us,
verses.comment: Luke refers to the apostolic tradition—what was seen and heard—passed down through trusted witnesses, emphasizing unbroken continuity and authority behind his account.

verses.text: It seemed good to me also, after carefully investigating everything from the start, to write to you in orderly sequence, most excellent Theophilus,
verses.comment: Luke claims thorough research and careful arrangement, suggesting the value of reason and tradition together in what he presents. 'Theophilus' may represent both a real person and all 'lovers of God.'

verses.text: So that you may know the certainty of the things you have been taught.
verses.comment: Luke emphasizes the reliability of the teaching, highlighting how faith is grounded in real events handed on with assurance.

verses.text: During the days of Herod, king of Judea, there was a priest named Zechariah, from the division of Abijah, and his wife Elizabeth was from the daughters of Aaron.
verses.comment: The narrative is anchored in history and lineage, connecting Zechariah and Elizabeth to priestly heritage, showing the fulfillment of God's promises through the temple and priesthood.

verses.text: Both were righteous before God, living blamelessly according to all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord.
verses.comment: Their righteousness highlights the role of personal holiness and obedience, preparing them as worthy vessels for God's action.

verses.text: Yet they had no child, because Elizabeth was barren, and both were advanced in years.
verses.comment: Drawing on the motif of miraculous births, God often works through human barrenness to show His power and mercy.

verses.text: Now while he was serving as priest before God when his division was on duty,
verses.comment: Zechariah's priestly service places this event within the liturgical life of Israel.

verses.text: He was chosen by lot, according to the custom of the priesthood, to enter the temple of the Lord and burn incense.
verses.comment: Incense offering symbolizes prayer rising to God; Zechariah's selection is providential, pointing to God's sovereign action.

verses.text: And the whole multitude of the people were praying outside at the hour of incense.
verses.comment: Communal prayer during the incense offering previously foreshadowed the gathered worship of believers.

verses.text: Then an angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing on the right side of the altar of incense.
verses.comment: The angel’s appearance marks a decisive divine intervention, often occurring at altars, hinting at God’s presence in worship.

verses.text: And Zechariah was troubled when he saw him, and fear fell upon him.
verses.comment: Fear in the presence of the angel indicates awe before God’s messengers, underscoring the gravity of this moment.

verses.text: But the angel said to him, 'Do not be afraid, Zechariah, for your prayer has been heard. Your wife Elizabeth will bear you a son, and you shall name him John.'
verses.comment: Miraculous announcement parallels Old Testament birth stories, reinforcing God's response to faithful prayer.

verses.text: He will bring you joy and gladness, and many will rejoice at his birth.
verses.comment: John’s birth brings joy not only to his parents but to the wider community, preparing the way for salvation history.

verses.text: For he will be great in the sight of the Lord. He must not drink wine or strong drink, and he will be filled with the Holy Spirit even from his mother’s womb.
verses.comment: John is set apart with a special consecration like a Nazirite, being filled with the Spirit from conception signals his prophetic office.

verses.text: And he will turn many of the children of Israel to the Lord their God.
verses.comment: John’s ministry has a strong call to repentance, fulfilling the prophetic expectation to restore Israel.

verses.text: He will go before Him in the spirit and power of Elijah, to turn the hearts of fathers to their children, and the disobedient to the wisdom of the just, to make ready a people prepared for the Lord.
verses.comment: Prophetic fulfillment: John’s role echoes Elijah, signaling the coming of the Messiah as foretold.

verses.text: And Zechariah said to the angel, 'How will I know this? For I am an old man, and my wife is advanced in years.'
verses.comment: Zechariah’s doubt resembles Abraham’s skepticism, showing human frailty before divine promise.

verses.text: The angel answered him, 'I am Gabriel, who stands in the presence of God. I was sent to speak to you and to bring you this good news.'
verses.comment: Gabriel’s self-identification confirms his authority and the message’s divine origin, linking to the angel’s previous appearances to Daniel.

verses.text: But now you will be silent and unable to speak until the day these things happen, because you did not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their proper time.
verses.comment: Zechariah’s silence is both a sign and a discipline, echoing Old Testament prophets who were temporarily silenced.

verses.text: Meanwhile, the people were waiting for Zechariah and were amazed that he delayed in the temple.
verses.comment: His delay suggests something remarkable was occurring, increasing expectation among the people.

verses.text: When he came out, he could not speak to them, and they realized he had seen a vision in the temple; he kept making signs to them and remained mute.
verses.comment: The inability to speak highlights the supernatural nature of what has occurred, while sign language alludes to prophetic signs.

verses.text: When his time of service was ended, he went to his home.
verses.comment: He completes his priestly duty, underscoring faithfulness even amidst personal supernatural experience.

verses.text: After these days his wife Elizabeth conceived, and she remained in seclusion for five months, saying,
verses.comment: Elizabeth’s conception is a fulfillment of God’s promise; her seclusion reflects preparation for the coming event.

verses.text: 'This is what the Lord has done for me in these days, when He looked on me, to take away my shame among the people.'
verses.comment: Removal of shame and vindication from God is a recurring biblical theme, stressing both individual restoration and social honor.

verses.text: In the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent from God to a town in Galilee named Nazareth,
verses.comment: Luke transitions to a new annunciation, this time to a humble, obscure town, preparing for the coming of the Messiah.

verses.text: To a virgin pledged in marriage to a man named Joseph, of the house of David. The virgin’s name was Mary.
verses.comment: Mary’s virginity and Davidic lineage fulfill prophetic anticipation, specifically Isaiah’s promise of a virgin bearing Emmanuel.

verses.text: And the angel came to her and said, 'Greetings, you who are highly favored! The Lord is with you.'
verses.comment: The angel’s greeting sets Mary apart for a unique mission. The phrase ‘highly favored’ denotes being chosen especially by God.

verses.text: But she was greatly troubled by his words and pondered what kind of greeting this might be.
verses.comment: Mary’s response shows humility and discernment; she is not naïve but thoughtful about God’s intervention.

verses.text: Then the angel said to her, 'Do not be afraid, Mary, for you have found favor with God.'
verses.comment: Finding favor with God is the foundation of redemption history, alluding to figures like Noah.

verses.text: You will conceive in your womb and bear a son, and you shall name Him Jesus.
verses.comment: The announcement of Jesus’ birth is worded similarly to prophetic oracles—God’s initiative in salvation and name-giving (reflecting authority).

verses.text: He will be great, and will be called the Son of the Most High, and the Lord God will give Him the throne of His father David.
verses.comment: The title 'Son of the Most High' marks Jesus’ divine status. His eternal Davidic kingship fulfills Old Testament prophecy, affirming both the literal and spiritual Messiahship.

verses.text: He will reign over the house of Jacob forever, and of His kingdom there will be no end.
verses.comment: Jesus’ everlasting rule is an explicit claim to divinity—earthly and spiritual reign fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: Mary said to the angel, 'How will this be, since I do not know a man?'
verses.comment: Mary’s question expresses wonder rather than doubt, highlighting her purity and readiness for God's new act.

verses.text: The angel answered, 'The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. Therefore, the child to be born will be holy, the Son of God.'
verses.comment: The involvement of the Holy Spirit points to Jesus’ divine origin. 'Overshadow' echoes God’s protective presence in the Old Testament, indicating sanctification and divine initiative.

verses.text: And behold, your relative Elizabeth has also conceived a son in her old age, and this is the sixth month for her who was called barren.
verses.comment: Miraculous conception links Mary’s promise to those of Sarah and others, strengthening her faith by God’s past actions.

verses.text: For nothing will be impossible with God.
verses.comment: The angel reaffirming God’s omnipotence recalls numerous Old Testament instances where God does the impossible.

verses.text: Mary said, 'Behold, I am the servant of the Lord; let it be to me according to your word.' And the angel departed from her.
verses.comment: Mary’s fiat—her affirmation and surrender—sets her as a model of faith. Both literal and spiritual interpretations stress her special role in salvation history.

verses.text: In those days Mary arose and went with haste into the hill country, to a town of Judah,
verses.comment: Mary’s visit reflects prompt obedience to grace and mission, paralleling movements of prophets and patriarchs.

verses.text: And she entered the house of Zechariah and greeted Elizabeth.
verses.comment: Hospitality and fellowship mark this scene, foreshadowing later gatherings of believers in homes.

verses.text: And when Elizabeth heard Mary’s greeting, the baby leaped in her womb. Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit
verses.comment: John’s recognition of Jesus, even in the womb, marks a spiritual encounter and prefigures New Testament pneumatology.

verses.text: And she exclaimed with a loud cry, 'Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the fruit of your womb!'
verses.comment: Elizabeth’s blessing elevates Mary’s unique role and the sacredness of her child; traditional Christian prayers echo this.

verses.text: Why is this granted to me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?
verses.comment: Elizabeth recognizes Jesus as 'Lord', affirming His divinity even before birth. The phrase 'mother of my Lord' carries subtle hints of reverence for Mary’s role.

verses.text: For behold, when the sound of your greeting came to my ears, the baby in my womb leaped for joy.
verses.comment: John’s leap, moved by spiritual joy, points to the efficacy of Christ’s presence and the Spirit working before birth.

verses.text: And blessed is she who believed that what was spoken to her from the Lord would be fulfilled.
verses.comment: Mary’s faith is praised, connecting her trust to Abraham’s faith credited as righteousness—important literal and spiritual parallel.

verses.text: And Mary said, 'My soul magnifies the Lord,
verses.comment: Mary’s ‘Magnificat’ echoes Hannah’s song; her spirituality models praise and humility before God.

verses.text: And my spirit rejoices in God my Savior,
verses.comment: Mary acknowledges her need for salvation, underscoring the universality of redemption.

verses.text: For He has looked upon the humble estate of His servant. For behold, from now on all generations will call me blessed;
verses.comment: Biblical prophecy of universal veneration of Mary and her blessing, echoing the spiritual meaning of the blessed among women.

verses.text: For He Who is mighty has done great things for me, and holy is His name.
verses.comment: God’s mighty works are revealed through Mary, showing her role as recipient and witness to divine action.

verses.text: And His mercy is for those who fear Him from generation to generation.
verses.comment: Her hymn highlights God’s steadfast mercy, linking the Old Testament to the New and including all generations in God’s plan.

verses.text: He has shown strength with His arm; He has scattered the proud in the thoughts of their hearts.
verses.comment: The arm of God is a symbol of His saving power—Mary’s song proclaims His victory over pride and injustice.

verses.text: He has brought down the mighty from their thrones and exalted those of humble position.
verses.comment: God’s reversal exalts the lowly, a theme central in both Testaments and realized in Mary and Jesus’ ministry.

verses.text: He has filled the hungry with good things, and the rich He has sent empty away.
verses.comment: Spiritual and literal hunger is satisfied in God; Mary proclaims kingdom realities where the last are first.

verses.text: He has helped His servant Israel, in remembrance of His mercy,
verses.comment: Mary’s song anchors salvation in God’s historic covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: As He spoke to our fathers, to Abraham and to his offspring forever.
verses.comment: Her praise connects Jesus’ birth directly to the Abrahamic promise, stressing continuity from Old Testament promise to New Testament fulfillment.

verses.text: Mary remained with her about three months and then returned to her home.
verses.comment: Mary’s stay suggests close communion; the three months likely coincide with Elizabeth’s delivery.

verses.text: Now the time came for Elizabeth to give birth, and she bore a son.
verses.comment: God’s promise to Elizabeth is fulfilled; parallels to promised births emphasize divine reliability.

verses.text: Her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had shown great mercy to her, and they rejoiced with her.
verses.comment: Communal joy follows personal blessing—Old Testament echoes of Sarah and community rejoicing over God’s mercy.

verses.text: On the eighth day they came to circumcise the child, and they were going to name him after his father Zechariah.
verses.comment: Circumcision on the eighth day observes Jewish law, signifying covenant inclusion.

verses.text: But his mother answered, 'No, he shall be called John.'
verses.comment: Elizabeth’s insistence obeys God’s angelic revelation; divine naming overrides tradition.

verses.text: They said to her, 'None of your relatives is called by this name.'
verses.comment: Naming conventions typically followed family lines, but here God’s choice signals a break and a new work.

verses.text: So they made signs to his father, asking what he would like him to be called.
verses.comment: Since Zechariah was mute, the crowd seeks his authoritative decision—emphasizing the role of parental consent in Jewish culture.

verses.text: He asked for a writing tablet and wrote, 'His name is John.' And they all wondered.
verses.comment: Zechariah’s obedience is made public, confirming the angel’s prophecy; the crowd’s amazement points to the supernatural nature of events.

verses.text: Immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue loosened, and he spoke, blessing God.
verses.comment: Fulfillment of the angel’s word; Zechariah’s restored speech is used to glorify God, showing the purpose of miracles.

verses.text: Fear came upon all who lived around them, and all these things were talked about in all the hill country of Judea.
verses.comment: Local awe and the spread of news highlight the power and reach of God’s intervention.

verses.text: And all who heard them laid them up in their hearts, saying, 'What then will this child be?' For the hand of the Lord was with him.
verses.comment: John’s future is acknowledged as special; people treasure the events, paralleling similar responses to Jesus.

verses.text: And his father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit and prophesied, saying:
verses.comment: Prophecy here signals Spirit-inspired speech, validating Zechariah as an authentic mouthpiece for God.

verses.text: 'Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, for He has visited and redeemed His people
verses.comment: God’s visitation is a technical Old Testament term for divine intervention and mercy.

verses.text: And has raised up a horn of salvation for us in the house of His servant David,
verses.comment: Horn signifies strength and kingly power—Christ as the Davidic Messiah.

verses.text: As He spoke by the mouth of His holy prophets from long ago,
verses.comment: Emphasizes the reliability and unity of God’s saving work across history through His prophets.

verses.text: Salvation from our enemies and from the hand of all who hate us;
verses.comment: Reference to liberation from all oppression, both literal and spiritual.

verses.text: To show mercy to our fathers and to remember His holy covenant,
verses.comment: Restates the theme of covenant faithfulness—God fulfills His promises over generations.

verses.text: The oath that He swore to our father Abraham,
verses.comment: Jesus’ coming is grounded in the Abrahamic covenant, signifying the family and universal blessing brought forth.

verses.text: That we, being delivered from the hand of our enemies, might serve Him without fear,
verses.comment: The freedom won is for worship and service—a central biblical goal for redemption.

verses.text: In holiness and righteousness before Him all our days.
verses.comment: Lifelong, daily holiness is the purpose of redemption—service and sanctification in community.

verses.text: And you, child, will be called the prophet of the Most High, for you will go before the Lord to prepare His ways;
verses.comment: Zechariah identifies John as the forerunner, connecting him to ancient prophecies about the preparation for the coming of the Lord.

verses.text: To give knowledge of salvation to His people in the forgiveness of their sins,
verses.comment: Salvation encompasses forgiveness; John’s ministry points to the coming sacrificial work of Jesus.

verses.text: Because of the tender mercy of our God, whereby the sunrise from on high will visit us
verses.comment: Metaphor of the sunrise signals messianic illumination—light overcoming darkness, both literally and spiritually.

verses.text: To give light to those who sit in darkness and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet into the way of peace.
verses.comment: Divine light, a recurring theme, implies both physical and spiritual rescue; peace here references shalom, fullness of life in God.

verses.text: The child grew and became strong in spirit, and he was in the wilderness until the day of his public appearance to Israel.
verses.comment: John’s growth in spirit and the wilderness setting align him with prophetic tradition—preparing for his vital role in salvation history.
